docs.snippet: Zarzuela is a Spanish word referring to a sort of bouillabaisse and a palace near Madrid. But to musical theater lovers, it is recognized as the Spanish variety of operetta. Until recently, most of us had to content ourselves with the tantalizing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Zarzuela is a Spanish word referring to a sort of bouillabaisse and a palace near Madrid. But to musical theater lovers, it is recognized as the Spanish variety of operetta. Until recently, most of us had to content ourselves with the tantalizing morsels recorded by nearly every notable singer of Spanish extraction, including Victoria de los Angeles, Teresa Berganza, Montserrat Caballe, Alfred Kraus and Placido Domingo. Most have sung zarzuela in Spain and have often included zarzuela excerpts in their concerts here. This week sees a significant boost in New York's exposure to this Iberian specialty with the appearance on Wednesday and Thursday at Madison Square Garden of Mr. Domingo at the head of the Spanish revue, the ''Antologia de la Zarzuela.'' This follows the new production at the Repertorio Espanol, more modestly scaled, of the classic 1932 zarzuela, ''Luisa Fernanda.''

headline.main: SPAIN'S STYLE OF OPERETTA GOES ON DISPLAY

byline.original: By Richard Traubner; Richard Traubner, author of ''Operetta: A Theatrical History'' (Doubleday), writes frequently on musical theater and film

docs.snippet: The Wimbledon champion, Boris Becker, was eliminated from the $150,000 Kitzbuehel Head Cup Tournament today in a 6-3, 6-1 first-round loss to Diego Perez of Uruguay.   The 17-year-old West German made repeated unforced errors, especially on his...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Wimbledon champion, Boris Becker, was eliminated from the $150,000 Kitzbuehel Head Cup Tournament today in a 6-3, 6-1 first-round loss to Diego Perez of Uruguay. The 17-year-old West German made repeated unforced errors, especially on his backhand, in his second defeat since becoming the youngest-ever Wimbledon champion July 7.

docs.snippet: Mexico's Foreign Minister today criticized sentiments in favor of overthrowing the Nicaraguan Government, saying such an action would have ''very unfortunate consequences'' for Latin America.   The Foreign Minister, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, was...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mexico's Foreign Minister today criticized sentiments in favor of overthrowing the Nicaraguan Government, saying such an action would have ''very unfortunate consequences'' for Latin America. The Foreign Minister, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, was responding to a report that some Reagan Administration officials are saying that United States differences with Nicaragua cannot be resolved so long as the Sandinistas remain in power. ''We do not believe that the solution is by way of the removal of a legitimately constituted Government,'' Mr. Sepulveda said. He added that such an action could bring a ''possible rupture of the institutional order and legitimate systems of security,'' in Central America and elsewhere in Latin America.

docs.snippet: A committee of international banks has agreed in principle to reschedule $2 billion of Uruguay's foreign debt that matures for the rest of the decade, Citibank said yesterday.
docs.lead_paragraph: A committee of international banks has agreed in principle to reschedule $2 billion of Uruguay's foreign debt that matures for the rest of the decade, Citibank said yesterday.

docs.snippet: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today that he would meet with American ambassadors to Central America on Monday to explore ways to give new impetus to the search for peace in the region and support...
docs.lead_paragraph: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today that he would meet with American ambassadors to Central America on Monday to explore ways to give new impetus to the search for peace in the region and support elections in Guatemala and Honduras. A four-page working paper that circulated in the State Department last week in preparation for the meeting said that the so-called Contadora peace process ''remains central to our policy'' in Central America but that ''collapse would be better than a bad agreement.'' ''A good agreement remains the goal,'' it said. Mr. Abrams, interviewed by telephone today from Key West, where he stopped en route to Panama for the one-day gathering, said the paper did not reflect precisely what he planned to say to the ambassadors on the subject, but other State Department officials said it fit within established policy guidelines.

headline.main: U.S. ENVOYS MEET IN PANAMA TODAY TO DISCUSS LATIN PEACE EFFORTS

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The chief of protocol at the United Nations fears he ''will be submerged under the waves.'' The intelligence chief for the New York Police Department is studying where to park a mini-police headquarters on New York city streets. Four teams of workers...
docs.lead_paragraph: The chief of protocol at the United Nations fears he ''will be submerged under the waves.'' The intelligence chief for the New York Police Department is studying where to park a mini-police headquarters on New York city streets. Four teams of workers on scaffolds are fighting the clock to scrape away years of soot and rust from the 39-floor aluminum and steel United Nations headquarters. And the rumor mill is working overtime.

headline.main: THRONG OF KINGS, PRESIDENTS AND PREMIERS COMING TO U.N.

byline.original: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The man with one of the most delicate tasks for the next month is Aly I. Teymour, the United Nations chief of protocol. Part of his job is to greet all of the heads of state and government when they arrive at the airport, no matter the hour.

headline.main: Protocol for All And at All Hours

docs.snippet: The corps of journalists covering the United Nations expands dramatically as various heads of state arrive to address the Assembly. More than 200 reporters from Latin America are expected here this week to cover the appearances of the leaders of...
docs.lead_paragraph: The corps of journalists covering the United Nations expands dramatically as various heads of state arrive to address the Assembly. More than 200 reporters from Latin America are expected here this week to cover the appearances of the leaders of Brazil, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela.

headline.main: From Iranian Delegate, A Bouquet and a Message

docs.snippet: When she moved here from England three years ago, Jennifer Brown was mildly surprised to see the stone fences, winding roads and verdant countryside. ''Looks like home,'' she said.   She was more surprised to hear the British accents - in the shops,...
docs.lead_paragraph: When she moved here from England three years ago, Jennifer Brown was mildly surprised to see the stone fences, winding roads and verdant countryside. ''Looks like home,'' she said. She was more surprised to hear the British accents - in the shops, on the train, at the park. ''It even sounds like home,'' she said.

byline.original: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: SOVIET TURN TO SPEAK - The Soviet Union takes its turn at the podium today when Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze addresses the delegates. While Mr. Shevardnadze speaks, Avital Shcharansky, wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, a Soviet labor camp...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOVIET TURN TO SPEAK - The Soviet Union takes its turn at the podium today when Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze addresses the delegates. While Mr. Shevardnadze speaks, Avital Shcharansky, wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, a Soviet labor camp inmate, said she would hold what she calls a ''General Assembly of Truth'' from a symbolic prison cage outside the United Nations headquarters. The cage will be placed near the base of the Shcharansky Steps, so named by the New York City Council several years ago, at 43d Street and First Avenue.
